title: Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s Violin Phase and the Experience of Time, or Why Does Process Music Work?
abstract: Reich’sViolin Phasehas been mired in questions of time since its inception. In this article I present a theory of time in process music based on the notion of kinesthetic knowledge, and the synthesis of musical temporality through the generative (chronopoietic) and transformational (chronopraxial) acts of the body. I illustrate this theory with an analysis of Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s choreography toViolin Phase, arguing that the dance serves as a proto-theory of the piece by creating and transforming its temporal trajectory. I draw attention to the role of structural convergences and divergences between dance and music, as well as of the emerging “resulting patterns,” in establishing and maintaining an emotional connection between the dancer and her audience. By closely examining the relationship between the music and De Keersmaeker’s movements, how together they create the space of the dance, and how the energy accumulated through incessant repetition gives shape to the aesthetic event, I argue that the choreography draws attention to novel temporal aspects of Reich’s piece.

FN1.text: 1. Perhaps the most emphatic expression of this axiom can be found in Morgan ( 1980 ): “There is no question, of course, that music is a temporal art” (527). In general, it is not uncommon to encounter statements to the effect that “music is a temporal art through and through” ( Begbie 2000 , 29); that “time in music is an active force, not a ‘mere formality’” ( Zuckerkandl 1956 , 247); that “music is predominantly an art of time” ( Monelle 2010 , 81); that since music lacks the solidity of a physical object, and therefore cannot endure in time, its expressive content is intimately connected with its temporality; that when it comes to music, time and meaning are “inseparable” ( Dufrenne 1973 , 270). For a critical assessment of the assumptions underlying these and similar pronouncements, see Kozak ( 2020 ).

FN2.text: 2. For a discussion of the embodied basis of our temporal concepts, see Cox ( 2017 ).

FN3.text: 3. In his mini-manifesto “Music as Gradual Process” Reich concisely defines process music as “pieces of music that are, literally, processes. The distinctive thing about musical processes is that they determine all the note-to-note (sound-to-sound) details and the overall form simultaneously” ( 2002b , 34). For further discussion and a taxonomy of different types of processes in music, see Brown ( 2010 ).

FN4.text: 4. See, for example, Marcia Tucker’s statements about the 1969 performance of Violin Phase at the Whitney Exhibition titled Anti-Illusion: Procedures/Materials : “[Reich’s piece] offered no illusion of temporality . . . only a sense of an isolated present” which resulted from “a deliberate and unrelenting use of repetition” (see Tucker and Monte 1969 ); or Alan M. Kriegsman’s review, also from 1969, in The Washington Post : “as the repetitions proceed, rhythmic variations are introduced at an exceedingly slow rate, resulting in a kaleidoscopic compression and dilation of time. If it gets to you at all, the effect is hypnotic.” For commentary on these, see Cole ( 2014 ). More recently, Noble ( 2018 ) writes that “terms like ‘mystical,’ ‘narcotic,’ ‘entrancing,’ and ‘meditative’ are common currency in minimalist discourse, and the experience of time and timelessness is among the most central topics” ([51]). Michael Fried ( 1998 ) discusses the experience of time in minimalist plastic art.

FN5.text: 5. Peter Shelley ( 2013 ) notes that for both Ivanka Stoianova ( 1977 ) and Wim Mertens ( 1983 ), Reich’s process music lacks a goal. Stoianova, in particular, goes so far as to say that the goal of this music is goallessness, a concept that Shelley finds “too close to meaningless to be of much use” (50). Robert Fink ( 2005 ) also critiques the teleological/non-teleological binary; however, he replaces it with one of his own: between “classical” teleology of the music of “Beethoven, Brahms, Berg, the Beatles” and “recombinant” teleology of process music. In classically teleological pieces, the telos determines the form, such that a single tension-release arc encompasses the entire piece, and the scale of this arc is phenomenologically congruent to our perception of “quotidian bodily rhythms” (44). By contrast, recombinant teleologies may include tension-release arcs of different lengths and degrees of completion, or may create arcs on a scale that “far outstrips the ability of the individual human subject to imagine a congruent bodily response” (44).

FN6.text: 6. Kramer explicitly derives vertical time from Eastern Buddhist philosophy. Quoting Edward T. Hall ( 1984 ), Kramer writes: “My terms linear and non-linear correspond roughly to the philosophical distinction between becoming and being. These two concepts have echoed throughout the philosophy of time—indeed, all philosophy—for centuries. The idea of becoming is found most prominently in the linear logic that began in ancient Greece and culminated in modern Western philosophy and science. The idea of being, while certainly explored by Western thinkers, has received its strongest statement in the ‘inward-looking, highly disciplined Buddhist philosophies in which Zen plays a prominent part’” ( 1988 , 16).

FN7.text: 7. Potter ( 2000 ) calls this the Basic Unit.

FN8.text: 8. Cohn takes as the starting point of his critique Reich’s statements in “Music as Gradual Process” ( 2002b ) suggesting that the composer is not privy to any “secrets of nature” that are not available to the listener.

FN9.text: 9. It seems that already a few years after the piece’s 1967 premiere, discourse surrounding process music in general, and Violin Phase in particular, had shifted between different aesthetic commitments: from a Sol LeWitt-inspired idea of “directing focus away from authorial decision-making towards the seemingly autonomous aspects of phase shifting” ( Cole 2014 , 230), to highlighting the importance of the performer in bringing out the “resulting patterns” and creating the “raw materials” from which improvisation could be constructed. In fact, Reich himself backtracked from his mini-manifesto in a 1971 Musical Times interview with Michael Nyman, saying that “every piece of mine has some aesthetic decision in it as to exactly how many beats out of phase a pattern will shift against itself, and when the two voices become four, and when the four voices will become eight, and when the melodic resulting patterns will be doubled” (quoted in Cole 2014 , 238).

FN10.text: 10. As Cohn ( 1992 ) notes, “there is something paradoxical about the identification of ‘process’ with ‘timelessness,’ since a process without actual or metaphorical motion through time is inconceivable” (169). Expressing a similar perspective, Shelley ( 2013 ) writes that “if teleology is simply a matter of establishing goals, then it is difficult to imagine any music more goal-directed than Reich’s phasing pieces, which announce from their first moments exactly what path will direct the movement of the music” (49).

FN11.text: 11. As Peter Shelley ( 2013 ) keenly observes, it is impossible to unequivocally uncouple musical linearity from non-linearity—the matter is simply one of emphasis between cultural and historical contingency, on the one hand, and internal formal relation, on the other.

FN12.text: 12. Music scholars have at length explicated Husserl’s phenomenology of time. See especially Lochhead ( 1982 ) and Lewin ( 1986 ). For what is perhaps the most in-depth analysis of Husserl’s work in relation to musical experience and understanding, see Wiskus ( 2021 ).

FN13.text: 13. For a more extensive critique of Kramer’s vertical time, see chapter 6 in Kozak ( 2020 ).

FN14.text: 14. Arguably, this point is obscured by Kramer’s own prose. For example, he often uses the categories of linearity and non-linearity to make explicit claims about time itself, leading to a number of contradictions which he is ultimately forced to dismiss with sweeping, impossible assertions that time, in all of its undefinable mystery (“time must ultimately be taken as undefinable” p. 6), simply refers to a set of arbitrarily determined aspects of change. “Time is not an absolute reality,” he writes. “It means different things to different people,” and, as such, is not bound by what J. T. Fraser called the “law of contradiction” (25).

FN15.text: 15. This is evidenced by Kramer’s description of his own experience of listening to yet another vertical piece, Pages mystiques from Erik Satie’s Vexations . Kramer notes that his boredom was overcome only when he himself “entered the vertical time of the piece” and, having “left behind [his] habits of teleological listening,” “forgot about the music’s past and future” ( 1988 , 379).

FN16.text: 16. More precisely, Kramer delineates the extremes of this continuum with “goal-directed linear time,” on the one hand, and “vertical time” on the other.

FN17.text: 17. Interest in this kind of inter-media analysis, which might be seen as an extension of choreomusicology but with a focus on how the visual and kinesthetic dimensions change one’s experience of the music, has been on the rise in recent years. For example, Horlacher ( 2019 ) examines the relationship between music and dance in De Keersmaeker’s Piano Phase ; Leong ( 2020 ) focuses on A Love Supreme , a collaboration between De Keersmaeker and Salva Sanchis to the music of John Coltrane.
